Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, code editor glaring back at me. My phone buzzed again—another message from my husband, his words heavy with worry and fear. He needed me, needed my comfort, my presence, my reassurance. I could hear him pacing in the next room, the weight of his crisis pressing down on both of us. But on my screen, urgent emails piled up. The project manager’s subject lines grew more desperate: “Build stalled—need your module ASAP.” My team was waiting, the entire project hinging on my solution. I felt the pressure from both sides, my heart pulled toward my husband, my mind racing with technical problems. I wanted to be the anchor he needed, but I also knew the team was counting on me to deliver. The expectations clashed inside me, each demanding my full attention, each impossible to ignore. I stared at the screen, hands trembling, torn between the person I loved and the work I was responsible for, not knowing which role to answer first.
